Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Earth and Environmental Science Curricula in a Minority-Serving Institution by Integrating a Particle Size Analyzer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is enhancing the Earth and Environmental Science curriculum at New Jersey City University, a Hispanic-Serving Institution with diverse students in an urban setting, through acquisition and integration of an automated particle-size analyzer based on X-ray absorption. The instrument is being used to facilitate inquiry-based learning across a wide range of courses, with a particular focus on contaminated urban soils, and to support placed-based undergraduate research during the summers and in the academic year. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its well-crafted plan to achieve specific learning objectives related to skills in analytical and quantitative reasoning and problem solving. Broader impacts include increasing participation of diverse, urban students in the geoscience workforce, and promoting an interdisciplinary Urban Environmental Science Program that can serve as a model for similar institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enhancing the Earth and Environmental Science Curricula in a Minority-Serving Institution by Integrating a Particle Size Analyzer

New Jersey City University (NJCU) is a Hispanic-Serving Institution and has 77 % of minority students. NJCU’s mission is to provide a diverse population with an excellent university education. We envisage that student outcomes will be different in the near future because next generation students will face not only different/unforeseen but also global-scale economic and technological challenges and opportunities. However, with the help of this NFS-TUES award, we established a framework to address the essential 21st-century skills including but not limited to problem solving; creativity; analytical thinking; collaboration; and communication.  

 

During this project, the Department of Geoscience/Geography has undergone a comprehensive transformation of its research, curricula, and educational programs and changed its name to the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences to more accurately reflect its focus and mission, since Fall-2016.  The department has adopted a new mission which is to apply comprehensive, inter- and trans-disciplinary scientific, competency-based pedagogies to train the next generation of students, teachers, and policymakers who understand complex earth system sciences to manage our planet. Our aim is to empower citizens to think globally and act locally, and thus to be aware of their choices.

 

This TUES award provided funds for purchasing a desktop Particle Size Analyzer (PSA).  The technique is used to determine the size distribution of solid environmental samples including soil, sediments, and dust.  With the help of this project, we accomplished founding a brand-new Environmental Geochemistry Teaching and Research Laboratory.       

 

We integrated PSA together with other state-of-art instruments at the department in various courses (both introductory and advanced level courses), and hence we modified relevant syllabi.  We collaborated with other STEM departments, especially with the Biology department. We carried out undergraduate summer research projects and provided opportunities to undergraduate students from NJCU as well as Community Colleges and High Schools.  The students actively involved in sample collection, data gathering, and evaluation stages.  The students presented their research projects in regional/ national professional conferences, and local STEM showcases. As a result, we developed a comprehensive database focusing on chemical and physical characteristics of urban soil in Jersey City which turned into a long-term environmental quality monitoring project.

 

We discussed and presented the potential pedagogical impacts of this project. We realized that the student learning outcomes could vary drastically, and often reflect the students’ quantitative skills. This understanding leads us to rethink about basic math requirements for the B.S. Environmental Science major.   In summary, we identified and implemented curricular goals to enhance student learning by providing hands-on, inquiry-based and student-centered learning and research experiences.
